isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (NAVPAK) (1997) - SECTION 2.3: PERFORMANCE DIAGNOSTICS - T 444E ENGINE - SUFFICIENT FUEL/PRESSURE

svcprocinfo.para:
Refer to Table 2.16
for the check engine oil level procedure.

table.title: Table 2.16 Sufficient Fuel/Pressure FROM FORM EGED-195

entry.para: Measure fuel pressure at regulator block

para.emph: If pressure is low, replace fuel filter, clean fuel strainer and retest.
If pressure is still low, proceed with step 2b.

svcsubproc.title: Purpose
svcsubproc.para: To determine if the fuel system is getting sufficient clean fuel at proper pressure to start and operate the engine.

svcsubproc.title: Sufficient/Clean Fuel Test Procedure

step1.para: Obtain fuel sample from fuel tank.

note.para: Fuel must be of proper grade, clean and undiluted.

step1.para: Inspect fuel in container. It must be clean and free of air, contaminants, water, icing or clouding. The fuel should be straw colored. Fuel dyed red or blue indicates an off-highway fuel.
Check fuel odor for the presence of other fuels such as gasoline or kerosene.

svcsubproc.para: If engine oil is present in the fuel, it may indicate an injector "O" ring leak and subsequent loss of injection control pressure. Refer to Test 10, ICP Pressure, and ICP Leakage Testfor determining the cause of oil present in the fuel. After the cause has been determined and the repair made, drain the fuel tank(s) and dispose of the contaminated fuel properly.

step1.para:
Connect a line from the fitting to the 0 -160 psi gauge on Gauge Bar (PS94-831-3) ( Figure 2.40
). Start engine and run at low idle to check for fuel leaks in line to the pressure gauge.

note.para: Bleed air from fuel line connected to pressure gauge to insure an accurate reading.

step1.para: Measure fuel pressure at high idle. Record pressure on diagnostic form and compare to specifications. If fuel pressure is not within specifications replace fuel filter, clean fuel strainer and retest.

note.para: It may take a number of crank cycles to purge the air out of the fuel system after replacing the fuel filter.

para.emph: If pressure is low after replacing the filter and cleaning the strainer, perform Transfer Pump Restriction Test 2b.

figure.caption: Figure 2.39 Pipe Plug Location On Fuel Regulator Block
Figure 2.40 Measuring Fuel Pressure with Gauge Bar (PS94-831-3)

svcsubproc.title: Low Or No Fuel Pressure Possible Causes

item.para: If equipped with a inline fuel valve, it could be shut off.
Fuel supply line from tank(s) could be broken or crimped.

Fuel could be waxed or jelled (most likely in cold weather with #2 fuel), the pickup tube in tank could be clogged or cracked. If there is excessive water in the tank, it could freeze preventing the fuel from being drawn to the engine.
If the vehicle is equipped with supplemental filters or water separators, check for plugged filters or leakage that could allow the fuel system to draw air.

Cloudy fuel indicates that the fuel may not be a suitable grade for cold temperatures. Excessive water or contaminants in fuel may indicate that the tank and fuel system may need to be flushed and cleaned.

svcsubproc.title: Tools Required
svcsubproc.para: Clear container approximately 1 quart. Gauge Bar (PS94-831-3), or Model D-200 Pressure Test Kit (ZTSE-2239) (0 to 160 PSI fuel pressure gauge), or fuel pressure gauge and appropriate line with 1/8" NPT fitting.
